Now, she was gone. Just like that. Taken by a cruel disease that had eaten away at her, leaving him alone with his regrets and his contemptuous thoughts. How could he have been so blind? So selfish?

The world seemed to reflect his own inner landscape - cold, bleak, and empty. He wondered how he would fill this vast void left behind by her absence.

I looked out at the rain, beating against our window like it has a personal grudge. The weatherman said it'll be like this all week. The Williams down the street have a beautiful garden, all vibrant colors and lush greenery. Mine's just a sorry excuse for a patch of grass, brown and dead now that she's not here to take care of it.

I turned on the radio, hoping for some distraction. But all they're playing are love songs, reminders of what I had and lost. I switched it off, plunging the room back into silence. It's not fair, really. Others seem to manage better than me. They've got more reason to complain, but here I am, wallowing in self-pity.
